list.name: Saudi Arabia
list.caption: Saudi Arabia exported 7.9 million barrels per day in 2010. Oil export earnings account for 75% of government revenues.

list.name: Russia
list.caption: Russia exported 7.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Production, consumption and net exports are steady. Data for Russia by itself are unavailable prior to the Soviet breakup.

list.name: Iran
list.caption: Iran exported 2.4 million barrels per day in 2010. Production increases are barely keeping pace with increased consumption. Net exports are trending downward.

list.name: UAE
list.caption: UAE exported 2.3 million barrels per day in 2010. Production is currently rising more slowly than consumption.

list.name: Nigeria
list.caption: Nigeria exported 2.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Oil export earnings account for 40% of government revenues.

list.name: Kuwait
list.caption: Kuwait exported 2.1 million barrels per day in 2010. Oil export earnings account for 95% of government revenues. Most Kuwaiti oil is exported to Asian markets.

list.name: Norway
list.caption: Norway exported 1.9 million barrels per day in 2010. Norway is the largest European exporter after Russia. The UK is the top importer of Norwegian oil.

list.name: Angola
list.caption: Angola exported 1.9 million barrels per day in 2010. Exports are up significantly. Oil export earnings account for 75% of government revenues.

list.name: Algeria
list.caption: Algeria exported 1.8 million barrels per day in 2010. Algeria's Saharan Blend oil, 45 degree API and 0.1 percent sulfur content, is among the highest quality in the world.

list.name: Iraq
list.caption: Iraq exported 1.7 million barrels per day in 2010. Iraqi exports are held in check by severe constraints in the refining and export infrastrucutre.

list.name: Venezuela
list.caption: Venezuela exported 1.6 million barrels per day in 2010. Exports have been in decline for a decades despite extensive 'heavy oil' reserves.

list.name: Libya
list.caption: Libya exported 1.5 million barrels per day in 2010. Hydrocarbon exports accounted for 95% of government revenue in 2010. The 2011 revolution has greatly restricted exports.

list.name: Kazakhstan
list.caption: Kazakhstan exported 1.4 million barrels per day in 2010. Kazakhstan has no sea ports. Exports are currently constrained by barge, pipeline and rail capacity.

list.name: Qatar
list.caption: Qatar exported 1.3 million barrels per day in 2010. Exports are steadily increasing. Most Qatari exports are destined for Japan and Korea.

list.name: Canada
list.caption: Canada exported 1.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Exports are steadily increasing. Canada is the #1 supplier of crude to the US.

list.name: Azerbaijan
list.caption: Azerbaijan exported 937 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The world's first oil well was drilled in 1846 in Azerbaijan. Production and net exports are up significantly.

list.name: Mexico
list.caption: Mexico exported 842 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Oil export earnings account for 75% of government revenues. Mxico is the #2 supplier of crude to the US.

list.name: Oman
list.caption: Oman exported 726 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Colombia
list.caption: Colombia exported 505 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has risen recently and is anticipated to increase to 1.2 mbd by 2012.

list.name: Sudan
list.caption: Sudan exported 416 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and net exports are up significantly. The recent partition of North and South may impact this trend.

list.name: Equatorial Guinea
list.caption: Equatorial Guinea exported 321 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The rapid rise in offshore production has now tapered off. The US is the #1 destination for Guinean oil.

list.name: Congo - Brazzaville
list.caption: Congo - Brazzaville exported 291 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has been rising. Consumption is still negligable.

list.name: Ecuador
list.caption: Ecuador exported 285 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Since 2004, net exports have been in steady decline. The 1987 earthquake halved exports.

list.name: Gabon
list.caption: Gabon exported 210 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Argentina
list.caption: Argentina exported 145 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Trends of declining production and increasing consumption look set to soon convert Argentina into a net importer.

list.name: Brunei
list.caption: Brunei exported 142 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Chad
list.caption: Chad exported 124 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Syria
list.caption: Syria exported 109 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The production peak is evident but the events of 2011 will dramatically alter both production and consumption

list.name: Trinidad and Tobago
list.caption: Trinidad and Tobago exported 104 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Malaysia
list.caption: Malaysia exported 104 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Trends of declining production and increasing consumption look set to soon convert Malaysia into a net importer.

list.name: Yemen
list.caption: Yemen exported 102 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Yemen is well past peak production. Current unrest will likely reduce production quantities.

list.name: Brazil
list.caption: Brazil exported 92 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has risen sharply and Brazil is now a (small) net exporter.

list.name: East Timor
list.caption: East Timor exported 85 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Turkmenistan
list.caption: Turkmenistan exported 83 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Denmark
list.caption: Denmark exported 81 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Danish production displays a well defined peak. Net exports have entered a steady decline.

list.name: Vietnam
list.caption: Vietnam exported 53 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production has stabilized after a rapid rise but consuption is still rising. Net exports are in decline.

list.name: Cameroon
list.caption: Cameroon exported 35 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Ivory Coast
list.caption: Ivory Coast exported 20 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Congo - Kinshasa
list.caption: Congo - Kinshasa exported 8 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Ukraine
list.caption: Ukraine imported 214 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Ukrainian oil consumption is down sharply since the fall of the Soviet Union.

list.name: United Kingdom
list.caption: United Kingdom imported 233 thousand barrels per day in 2010. The Piper Alpha disaster in 1988 reduced offshore production for several years. Since 2000, UK oil fields have been in steady decline.

list.name: Israel
list.caption: Israel imported 234 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Switzerland
list.caption: Switzerland imported 251 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Austria
list.caption: Austria imported 252 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Portugal
list.caption: Portugal imported 267 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Indonesia
list.caption: Indonesia imported 272 thousand barrels per day in 2010. A classic example of the 'Export Land Model', production has fallen behind consumption and this previous OPEC member now imports oil.

list.name: Philippines
list.caption: Philippines imported 277 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Chile
list.caption: Chile imported 294 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Hong Kong SAR China
list.caption: Hong Kong SAR China imported 333 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Pakistan
list.caption: Pakistan imported 346 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Increasing oil imports have generated a sever balance of payments problem in Pakistan.

list.name: Sweden
list.caption: Sweden imported 360 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: South Africa
list.caption: South Africa imported 361 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Greece

list.name: Australia

list.name: Turkey

list.name: Poland
list.caption: Poland imported 538 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Belgium
list.caption: Belgium imported 589 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Thailand
list.caption: Thailand imported 645 thousand barrels per day in 2010. Production and consumption are both rising in this net oil importer.

list.name: Netherlands
list.caption: Netherlands imported 968 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Taiwan
list.caption: Taiwan imported 975 thousand barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Singapore
list.caption: Singapore imported 1.1 million barrels per day in 2010.

list.name: Italy
list.caption: Italy imported 1.4 million barrels per day in 2010. With little production of their own, increasing prices in Italy are driving down consumption.

list.name: Spain
list.caption: Spain imported 1.4 million barrels per day in 2010. Spanish consumption increased during the boom of the previous decade. Spain is currently the #8 oil importer.

list.name: France
list.caption: France imported 1.7 million barrels per day in 2010. French consumption and imports of oil have been steady for almost three decades. France is the #7 oil importer.

list.name: South Korea
list.caption: South Korea imported 2.2 million barrels per day in 2010. South Korea is the #6 oil importer.

list.name: India
list.caption: India imported 2.2 million barrels per day in 2010. Similar to China, Indian production is up only slightly in the face of rapidly increasing consumption.

list.name: Germany
list.caption: Germany imported 2.3 million barrels per day in 2010. Germany is the #4 oil importer.

list.name: Japan
list.caption: Japan imported 4.3 million barrels per day in 2010. In 2010 Japan was the #3 oil importer. In 2011 imports are rising due the closure of damaged nuclear plants.

list.name: China
list.caption: China imported 4.9 million barrels per day in 2010. Production is still rising but cannot keep pace with consumption. Existing trends suggest that net imports will keep rising.

list.name: United States
list.caption: United States imported 9.5 million barrels per day in 2010. Production is up slightly while consumption is down. The US is the #1 oil importer.
